newsitem.title: CANADA: Inco talks in Manitoba to resume.
newsitem.headline: Inco talks in Manitoba to resume.

text.p: Inco Ltd and the union representing locked out workers at the company's Manitoba facility said on Wednesday they would resume negotiations on Thursday.
"We're going back to the bargaining table tomorrow at 10 a.m. (1100 EDT/1500 GMT)," said Bob Desjarlais, president of local 6166 of the United Steelworkers of America.

Almost 1,400 workers have been locked out of the nickel facility for more than a week after rejecting a contract offer from Inco. The facility produces about 100 million pounds of nickel a year or about 20 percent of Inco's total output.
The main stumbling blocks to a settlement have been shift scheduling and wages.
"It became clear that both sides wanted to get back to the table," Inco spokesman Dan McSweeney said. "We saw an opportunity for the talks to be fruitful."
The two sides had refused to meet because they said they were too far apart on the main issues.
But there were now signs of flexibility from both parties, said Desjarlais.
"Both sides realize the only way we can resolve this is by movement from both sides," he said.
